message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Distributed Competitive and Collaborative Coordination for Multirobot Systems
Paper Abstract: Enlightened by competitive and collaborative coordination behaviors widely observed in natural swarm systems, this work emphasizes these coordinating modes in multirobot systems and optimizes system stability along with resource utilization. Then, schemes are constructed to describe and model these two modes, where a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$k$</tex-math></inline-formula> -winner-take-all concept is introduced as the driving principle of multirobot competition. In addition, a distributed coordination approach is established to effectively handle the above schemes aided with optimality theory, which is developed by a fusion of a recurrent neural dynamics solver and a distributed solver. The former is a single-layer neural dynamics model with a simple structure, and the latter transforms the involved global information to a distributed type via consensus. Both of them are carried out in the discrete-time domain to fit the actual application. Finally, the convergence and stability of the proposed coordination approach are proved via theoretical analysis and further demonstrated through simulations and experiments.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the results for **Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)**:

## Definition and Purpose

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) are designed for processing sequential data, such as text, speech, and time series, where the order of elements is important.(no content)Unlike feedforward neural networks, which process inputs independently, RNNs utilize recurrent connections, where the output of a neuron at one time step is fed back as input to the network at the next time step.

## Key Mechanism

The fundamental building block of RNN is the recurrent unit, which maintains a hidden state—a form of memory that is updated at each time step based on the current input and the previous hidden state.(no content)This enables RNNs to capture temporal dependencies and patterns within sequences.

## Applications

RNNs have been successfully applied to tasks such as unsegmented, connected handwriting recognition, speech recognition, natural language processing, and neural machine translation.

## Notable Variants

Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks were invented by Hochreiter and Schmidhuber in 1995 and set accuracy records in multiple applications domains.(no content)Bidirectional recurrent neural networks (BRNN) use two RNNs that process the same input in opposite directions.

Web search results for query: "Distributed computing"

Links: [{"title":"Distributed computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing"},{"title":"Distributed Computing Environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_Computing_Environment"},{"title":"Distributed networking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_networking"},{"title":"Advances in Distributed Computing and Artificial Intelligence Journal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advances_in_Distributed_Computing_and_Artificial_Intelligence_Journal"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Grid computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grid_computing"},{"title":"Edge computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edge_computing"},{"title":"Parallel computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_computing"},{"title":"Cloud computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cloud_computing"},{"title":"Cambridge Distributed Computing System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambridge_Distributed_Computing_System"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about distributed computing:

## Definition and Core Concept

Distributed computing is a field of computer science that studies distributed systems, defined as computer systems whose inter-communicating components are located on different networked computers.(no content)In distributed computing, a problem is divided into many tasks, each of which is solved by one or more computers, which communicate with each other via message passing.

## How It Works

The components of a distributed system communicate and coordinate their actions by passing messages to one another in order to achieve a common goal.(no content)There are several autonomous computational entities (computers or nodes), each of which has its own local memory, and the entities communicate with each other by message passing.

## Key Characteristics and Challenges

Three challenges of distributed systems are: maintaining concurrency of components, overcoming the lack of a global clock, and managing the independent failure of components.(no content)When a component of one system fails, the entire system does not fail.

## Advantages and Disadvantages

A well-designed distributed system is more scalable, more durable, more changeable, and more fine-tuned than a monolithic application deployed on a single machine. However, distributed systems cost more than monolithic architectures, primarily due to increased needs for additional hardware, servers, gateways, firewalls, new subnets, proxies, and so on.

## Practical Applications

Examples of distributed systems vary from SOA-based systems to microservices to massively multiplayer online games to peer-to-peer applications.

Web search results for query: "Multi-agent coordination"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Distributed artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"},{"title":"Multi-agency coordination","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agency_coordination"},{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human–robot_collaboration"},{"title":"Multi-Agent Programming Contest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-Agent_Programming_Contest"},{"title":"Agentic AI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agentic_AI"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about multi-agent coordination:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents that can solve problems which are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Definition and Focus

In computer science, multi-agent planning involves coordinating the resources and activities of multiple agents.(no content)This can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

## Key Aspects

Middleware offers a first-class design abstraction for multi-agent systems, providing means to govern resource access and agent coordination.(no content)When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language, within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement.

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Multi-agent systems are widely advocated for use in networking and mobile technologies to achieve automatic and dynamic load balancing, coordinated defence systems, and are being used in transportation, logistics, graphics, manufacturing, power systems, smartgrids, and geographic information systems.

Based on the search results, here's information about control theory stability:

## Overview

Control theory aims to develop a model or algorithm governing the application of system inputs to drive the system to a desired state, while minimizing delay, overshoot, or steady-state error and ensuring a level of control stability.

## Stability Criteria

In control theory and stability theory, a stability criterion establishes when a system is stable. Several important approaches exist:

- **Linear Systems**: The stability of a linear system can be determined by solving the differential equation to find the eigenvalues, or without solving the equation by using the Routh–Hurwitz stability criterion.

- **Frequency Domain Methods**: Linear time-invariant systems are amenable to powerful frequency domain mathematical techniques such as the Laplace transform, Fourier transform, Z transform, Bode plot, root locus, and Nyquist stability criterion.

- **Lyapunov Methods**: A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.

## Key Stability Concepts

A central theme of control theory is feedback regulation—the design of a feedback controller to achieve stability and a level of performance for a given dynamical system.(no content)Input-to-state stability (ISS) is a stability notion widely used to study stability of nonlinear control systems with external inputs. A control system is ISS if it is globally asymptotically stable in the absence of external inputs and if its trajectories are bounded by a function of the size of the input.

Web search results for query: "Winner take all neural network"

Links: [{"title":"Winner-take-all (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner-take-all_(computing)"},{"title":"Competitive learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_learning"},{"title":"Winner-take-all in action selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner-take-all_in_action_selection"},{"title":"Category:Artificial neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Artificial_neural_networks"},{"title":"Lottery ticket hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lottery_ticket_hypothesis"},{"title":"Geoffrey Hinton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geoffrey_Hinton"},{"title":"Network neuroscience - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_neuroscience"},{"title":"Winner-take-all market - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner-take-all_market"},{"title":"Winner-take-all system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner-take-all_system"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about winner-take-all neural networks:

## Overview

Winner-take-all networks are commonly used in computational models of the brain, particularly for distributed decision-making or action selection in the cortex.(no content)Important examples include hierarchical models of vision, and models of selective attention and recognition.

## How It Works

The neuron with the largest output is selected, and the weights going into that neuron are modified according to the Instar learning rule. All other weights remain unchanged. This principle can be extended: The k-winners-take-all rule is similar, except that the Instar learning rule is applied to the weights going into the k neurons with the largest outputs.

## Competitive Learning Context

Competitive learning is a form of unsupervised learning in artificial neural networks, in which nodes compete for the right to respond to a subset of the input data.(no content)The neuron that wins the competition is called a "winner-take-all" neuron.

## Application in Robotics

In 1982, Jerome A. Feldman and D.H. Ballard published the "Connectionist Models and Their Properties", referencing and explaining winner-take-all as a method of action selection. Feldman's architecture functioned on the simple rule that in a network of interconnected action modules, each module will set its own output to zero if it reads a higher input than its own in any other module.

Based on the web search results, here's information about multirobot systems:

## Overview

Multirobot systems, also known as multi-robot systems, involve multiple interacting robots working together. A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Applications

Multirobot systems have diverse applications across various domains:

- Proprietary multi-robot systems—such as ServeSwift and Robot‑On‑Call—automate delivery and bussing processes in restaurants and hospitality environments.
- A multirobot coordination approach ensures robustness and promotes graceful degradation in team performance when faced with malfunctions, including communication failures, partial robot malfunction, or robot death.

## Swarm Robotics

One notable area of multirobot research is swarm robotics. Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, and robots cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.(no content)One of the first international projects regarding swarm robotics was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, in which a swarm of up to 20 of robots capable of independently physically connect to each other to form a cooperating system were used to study swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects, resulting in demonstration of self-organized teams of robots that cooperate to solve a complex task.

## Overview

- Proprietary multi-robot systems—such as ServeSwift and Robot‑On‑Call—automate delivery and bussing processes in restaurants and hospitality environments.

Web search results for query: "Consensus algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Consensus (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Chandra–Toueg consensus algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chandra–Toueg_consensus_algorithm"},{"title":"Raft (algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raft_(algorithm)"},{"title":"Paxos (computer science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paxos_(computer_science)"},{"title":"Consensus clustering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_clustering"},{"title":"Algorand - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorand_(cryptocurrency_platform)"},{"title":"Proof of work - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_of_work"},{"title":"Shapiro–Senapathy algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_Senapathy_algorithm"},{"title":"File:Raft Consensus Algorithm Mascot on transparent background.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Raft_Consensus_Algorithm_Mascot_on_transparent_background.svg"},{"title":"Computational phylogenetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_phylogenetics"}]

## Consensus Algorithm

Here are the key findings from the web search:

### Definition and Purpose

A consensus algorithm is a mechanism that requires agreement among a number of processes (or agents) on a single data value.(no content)This often requires coordinating processes to reach consensus, or agree on some data value that is needed during computation, with example applications including agreeing on what transactions to commit to a database in which order, state machine replication, and atomic broadcasts.

### Common Types and Examples

There are several well-known consensus algorithms used in distributed computing:

- **Paxos**: The Paxos consensus algorithm by Leslie Lamport, and variants of it such as Raft, are used pervasively in widely deployed distributed and cloud computing systems.

- **Raft**: Raft is a consensus algorithm designed as an alternative to the Paxos family of algorithms, meant to be more understandable than Paxos by means of separation of logic.

- **Byzantine-tolerant algorithms**: An example of a polynomial time binary consensus protocol that tolerates Byzantine failures is the Phase King algorithm by Garay and Berman, which solves consensus in a synchronous message passing model with n processes and up to f failures, provided n > 4f.

### Real-World Applications

Real-world applications often requiring consensus include cloud computing, clock synchronization, PageRank, opinion formation, smart power grids, state estimation, control of UAVs (and multiple robots/agents in general), load balancing, blockchain, and others.

Based on the search results, here's information about swarm robotics:

## Definition and Concept

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.(no content)They take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

## Key Characteristics

Robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings and provide feedback, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities such as wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish given tasks.(no content)Miniaturization is also a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach.

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.(no content)One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, which studied swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

## Applications

Applications include tasks that demand miniaturization, like distributed sensing tasks in micromachinery or the human body.(no content)A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "A Distributed Competitive and Collaborative Coordination for Multirobot Systems". Here's what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes novel methods and concepts)

**Triples Identified:** 8 key technologies and methodologies

| Entity Name | Relation | Type | Why It Matters |
|---|---|---|---|
| Multi-agent system | uses | concept | Foundational framework for coordinating multiple robots |
| Swarm robotics | uses | task | Inspires competitive and collaborative coordination behaviors |
| Recurrent neural network | uses | method | Basis for the neural dynamics solver |
| Winner-take-all (computing) | **proposes** | concept | Novel k-winner-take-all driving principle for competition |
| Consensus (computer science) | uses | method | Enables decentralized coordination via consensus |
| Distributed computing | uses | concept | Foundation for distributed coordination approach |
| Stability theory | uses | concept | Proves convergence and stability of the approach |
| Control theory | uses | concept | Mathematical framework for optimization and analysis |

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

The analysis correctly identifies:
- 1 "proposes" relation (the k-winner-take-all concept)
- 7 "uses" relations (building on existing work)
- Proper distribution of entity types (5 concepts, 1 task, 2 methods)

Sources:
- [Multi-agent system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system)
- [Swarm robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics)
- [Recurrent neural network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Recurrent_neural_network)
- [Winner-take-all (computing)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner-take-all_(computing))
- [Consensus (computer science)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_(computer_science))
- [Distributed computing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_computing)

- [Control theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory)
